abstract.p: Correction of Correspondent's Report article in July 23 Travel section regarding Americans' travel restrictions to Cuba

block.p: INTERNATIONAL

Clinton Leaves Japan To Resume Mideast Talks President Clinton cut short his meetings in Japan with leaders of the world's largest industrialized nations to return to Camp David and the search for a historic peace in the Middle East.
INTERNATIONAL

Clinton Leaves Japan To Resume Mideast Talks President Clinton cut short his meetings in Japan with leaders of the world's largest industrialized nations to return to Camp David and the search for a historic peace in the Middle East.

The peace teams at the Camp David summit meeting moved into a waiting-for-President-Clinton mode as the Jewish Sabbath imposed an informal day of small group discussions. American officials did not even divulge the daily schedule.

Azerbaijan Cautions Moscow President Heydar Aliyev of Azerbaijan has cautioned his Russian counterpart, Vladimir V. Putin, that he must deal with former Soviet republics as equals, not as former client states with interests and policies subservient to those of Moscow.

Pakistani Punished Further A special anticorruption court sentenced the country's deposed prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, who is already serving a life term in prison, to 14 years of hard labor, fined him $370,000, and disqualified him from politics for 21 years.

U.S. to Work with Peru Clinton administration officials, after denunciations of Peru's recent election, say they do not have enough leverage to force a new vote and will work with President Alberto K. Fujimori while pressing for reform.
NATIONAL

Serious Problems Found In Care at Nursing Homes Federal officials say that most nursing homes are understaffed to the point that patients may be endangered. The government is recommending strict new rules that would require thousands of the homes to hire more nurses and health aides.

Drug Firms Making Deals Brand and generic drug companies have sometimes joined hands to keep drugs off the market. The deals, which can lead to higher prices for consumers, are part of an effort to fend off competition from generics.
Bush Seeking Safe Choice Gov. George W. Bush seems to be steering toward the safe and solid in seeking a vice president, partly because the job is increasingly seen as more than an understudy role.
Democrats have unveiled a plan for their August convention that is intended to gently disengage Vice President Al Gore from President Clinton, while still celebrating Clinton's economic policies.
Ralph Nader, the Green Party candidate, is actively courting union members, with some success.

Couples Head for Vermont Most of the gay and lesbian couples taking advantage of Vermont's new measure allowing marriagelike civil unions are from out of state, even though the law probably stops working at the border.
NEW YORK/REGION

Mrs. Clinton Receives Warm Welcome at Synagogue In her first public appearance before a Jewish audience since she was accused of making an anti-Semitic slur, Hillary Rodham Clinton attended services at an Orthodox synagogue on Long Island and received a generally warm welcome. Mrs. Clinton did not directly mention the accusation, but she spent a good part of her talk stressing the importance of racial and ethnic understanding.

Drug Overdose in Chelsea Club A 21-year-old student visiting New York from Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore died apparently from an overdose of the designer drug ecstasy, after collapsing on the dance floor of Twilo, a popular nightclub on West 27th Street in Chelsea, the authorities said.
Fresh Air Fund
OBITUARIES
Josephine D. Martin A psychiatrist who was known as the unofficial doctor to the Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee as she counseled terrified civil rights activists, she was 84.

27 Weather
29 Cong. Vote
